title: Greensill, Gupta and an Italian bank collapse
text:
Mark your calendars: join the FT team, including DD's own Rob Smith and Arash Massoudi, as they take you inside the rise and fall of Greensill Capital and give you a front-row seat into the FT's reporting over the past three years. Register for the free online event here. (Don't forget to watch the FT film on the saga to get up to speed beforehand.)

Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.

An unexpected victim of the Greensill fallout

The Greensill Capital scandal has claimed another casualty. This time, it's not David Cameron's reputation or Credit Suisse's investment funds, but Aigis Banca, a speciality Italian lender, that has found itself entangled in the crisis involving the supply-chain finance firm.

Milan-based Aigis, which is backed by the private equity firm Metric Capital Partners, has collapsed into liquidation because of its exposure to Greensill and the embattled metals magnate Sanjeev Gupta.

Aigis's collapse could have caused “severe social and economic consequences” were it not for its peer Banca Ifis's agreement to buy its assets and liabilities for €1, according to the Ifis chief executive Frederik Geertman. Ifis stressed that Greensill-related securities weren't part of the deal.

The main issue: Aigis had bought receivables-backed notes, linked to Gupta's metals empire, from Greensill, DD's Rob Smith and Kaye Wiggins and the FT's Silvia Sciorilli Borrelli report. 

These were covered by insurance policies — but they are yet to pay out, people familiar with the matter said. 

That's not Aigis's only connection to Gupta. The metals tycoon had tried to buy a stake in the bank, which was previously called GBM Banca and renamed last year, at a time when his own UK bank Wyelands was coming under increasing scrutiny. 

A couple more Gupta updates for DD readers following the story closely: 

  • The governor of the Bank of England has revealed that Gupta's Wyelands bank was under scrutiny from the National Crime Agency and the Serious Fraud Office;

  • Gupta's UK steel business transferred part of a £7m taxpayer loan given to a struggling Scottish plant to elsewhere in his empire;

  • Gupta has put three of his UK steel plants up for sale and held talks with Credit Suisse about a possible debt standstill deal.

It's hard to know where the aftershocks of the Greensill saga will strike next. But it's worth keeping an eye on UK business secretary Kwasi Kwarteng's evidence to MPs on the House of Commons business, energy and industrial strategy committee today.  

Did you hear about the Morgans? 

Whenever JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon is asked about when he will step down from his role, the usual response has been “five years”. 

But as time goes on, the answer remains the same. It has become something of a joke on Wall Street. 

Needless to say, we have little clarity on when Dimon actually plans to step down from the throne. But we are getting a better idea of who will be in line to take over when the time comes. 

Last week JPMorgan named the longtime bankers Marianne Lake and Jennifer Piepszak as co-heads of its consumer and community banking unit — the bank's largest in terms of revenue.

They'll be taking over from one of Dimon's top lieutenants Gordon Smith, who steps down at the end of the year. It's a clear sign that both women are among the top candidates to succeed Dimon. But we shouldn't get ahead of ourselves. 

The truth is that Dimon doesn't plan to step down any time soon. The longtime CEO, who last year underwent emergency heart surgery, has been asked to stick around for a “significant number of additional years” by JPM's board, insiders told the FT's Joshua Franklin and Stephen Morris. That could mean anywhere between five and seven years.

A lot can happen in that time, including new contenders for the most-prized job on Wall Street.

Teresa Heitsenrether, who oversees security services, and Troy Rohrbaugh, who leads the trading operation, are still in the running. Both are seen as rising stars within JPMorgan's ranks, according to a person briefed on the matter.

And don't forget about Bill Demchak, the hyper-ambitious head of PNC Financial who bought BBVA's US business at the end of last year for $11.6bn. DD sources still think he's a very likely wild card when it comes to the succession game (as we told you a while back). 

Not to be outdone, Morgan Stanley kicked off a succession showdown of its own last week with CEO James Gorman making a series of management shake-ups. He promoted two top deputies, Ted Pick and Andy Saperstein, to be co-presidents.

Wall Street will need to choose its horses wisely. As the FT's Lex column points out, the new generation of banking bosses will face serious challenges from financial technology groups and powerful private capital institutions encroaching on their turf. 

While succession chatter was the talk of Wall Street last week, observers will turn their heads towards something new: the ways in which the next-gen group, having moved closer to the limelight, will begin to use their increasingly valuable political capital. 

From prison to espionage: Tom Hayes' next move

Tom Hayes, the trader convicted of rigging the Libor rate in 2015, spent five and a half years in prison. Now he's out, and he's reinventing himself — as a corporate spook. 

The former UBS and Citigroup banker is joining a new corporate espionage outfit set up by Seth Freedman, a former operative at the controversial corporate intelligence firm Black Cube.

Founded in 2011 by veterans of the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad, the group has been enlisted by wealthy patrons including the disgraced movie mogul Harvey Weinstein.

(Dive deeper into the industry with this DD take on Hakluyt, the London-based private intelligence firm founded by a band of MI6 officers.)

Hayes says the “new skills” he learnt in prison while fighting to overturn his conviction will help him in the job at Freedman's new corporate intelligence agency, Red Mist. He'll work as a consultant while separately continuing his own legal battle. 

In his new role, Hayes is going to focus on financial wrongdoing. Despite having been locked up for years, Hayes seems to have understood an important phenomenon: private spying is having a moment. 

Side note: one of the brokers cleared of helping Hayes rig the Libor rate, Danny Wilkinson, worked for Raidne, a company that sells “surveillance algorithms to monitor market manipulation and market abuse”, after his acquittal. 

But, at least according to his LinkedIn page, his career has since taken a different turn. 

Wilkinson, who also DJs in a house music collective that performs in lab coats, is now . . . a wine taster. 

Cheers to new beginnings.

Job moves

  • SoftBank's vice-chair Ron Fisher, who oversaw much of the Japanese group's $10bn-plus investment in WeWork, and its first female director Yuko Kawamoto are leaving the company's board in a major shake-up. Read more here.

  • Faryar Shirzad, a senior Goldman Sachs lobbyist, has joined Coinbase as its new chief policy officer. 

  • Tom Stoddard is appointed a Bank of America vice-chair of investment banking in New York. He joins from McKinsey & Company and previously was chief financial officer of Athora. 

  • Goldman Sachs is recruiting Kimberley Harris as an independent director on its board. She has served as an executive vice-president of Comcast since 2019 and an executive vice-president and general counsel of NBCUniversal since 2013.

  • Lazard has hired William McRaven, a retired US Navy admiral who oversaw the 2011 raid that killed Osama bin Laden, as a senior adviser in the investment bank's financial advisory business.

  • The hedge fund Schonfeld Strategic Advisors has recruited Colin Lancaster and his 11-person team from Matador Investment Management. He was previously head of macro strategies at Citadel.
